description.summary: Supernatural beings in Islamic theology and pre-Islamic Arabian mythology, created from smokeless fire. Possess free will, can be good or evil, and have abilities including shape-shifting and invisibility.
description.full: Djinn (jinn) are supernatural beings in Islamic theology and pre-Islamic Arabian mythology, created by God from smokeless fire (humans were created from clay, angels from light). They are invisible to humans under normal circumstances but can manifest in various forms. Djinn possess free will, meaning they can choose to be good, evil, or neutral, and are morally accountable for their actions just as humans are. In Islamic belief, djinn have their own societies parallel to humans, with families, religions, and nations. They can be Muslim or non-Muslim. Types of djinn include Marid (powerful), Ifrit (malevolent), Ghul (demonic), and Jann (least powerful). Djinn possess powers including shape-shifting, invisibility, possession, superhuman abilities, and flight. In Islamic tradition, the prophet Suleiman (Solomon) was granted control over djinn and used them to build temples and perform great works. The Quran mentions djinn extensively, and Iblis (Satan) is identified as a djinn who refused to bow to Adam. While Western popular culture often depicts genies as wish-granting spirits in lamps (from Arabian Nights tales), this is a significant misrepresentation; the 'three wishes' trope is not part of traditional Islamic or Arabian djinn theology.

etymology.origin: From Arabic 'jinn' (الجن), from the root j-n-n meaning 'to hide' or 'to conceal.' Refers to their hidden/invisible nature.
etymology.first_use: Pre-Islamic Arabian traditions; formally in Islamic texts from 7th century CE onward

related_phenomena.name: Angels (Malaika)
related_phenomena.description: Created from light, lack free will (in Islamic theology)

related_phenomena.name: Demons/Shayatin
related_phenomena.description: Evil djinn or offspring of Iblis

related_phenomena.name: Peri
related_phenomena.description: Persian supernatural beings, sometimes conflated with djinn

nature.creation: Smokeless fire (humans from clay, angels from light)
nature.visibility: Invisible to humans normally, can manifest
nature.free_will: Yes - can choose good, evil, or neutral
nature.accountability: Subject to divine judgment like humans

types.characteristics: Great power, often associated with water or air
types.notes: Often depicted in Arabian Nights stories

types.characteristics: Associated with fire, cunning, enormous power

types.notes: Prey on travelers, consume human flesh
Closest to original form of djinn

types.characteristics: Followers of Iblis (Satan), corrupt and tempt

abilities.description: Can take various forms including animals and humans
Naturally invisible to humans, can choose to manifest
Can fly or travel great distances rapidly
Live much longer than humans but are mortal

society.religion: In Islamic theology, djinn can be Muslim or non-Muslim, believers or disbelievers

range.description: Islamic world and pre-Islamic Arabian traditions. Belief in djinn spans from Middle East through North Africa, Central Asia, South Asia, and Southeast Asia.

origins.cultural_roots: Pre-Islamic Arabian mythology. Ancient Arabian belief in spirits of the desert, wind, and hidden places. Incorporated into Islamic theology with modifications.
origins.earliest_accounts: Pre-Islamic Arabic poetry and tribal beliefs dating to ancient times.
origins.islamic_integration: The Quran mentions djinn extensively, confirming their existence while placing them within Islamic monotheistic framework.

timeline.significance: Ancient Arabian traditions of spirits and supernatural beings
Djinn formally incorporated into Islamic theology, entire surah (Al-Jinn) dedicated to them
Islamic scholars elaborate on djinn nature, types, and interactions with humans
Folk tales including djinn stories (later source of Western 'genie' misrepresentations)
Arabian Nights translated to European languages, 'genie' concept enters Western culture
Disney's Aladdin and similar works create distorted 'three wishes genie' stereotype

history.modern_era: Djinn remain part of living Islamic religious belief for millions of Muslims worldwide. Concurrently, Western popular culture has created a significantly distorted 'genie' concept largely disconnected from authentic Islamic theology.

quranic_references.free_will: Possess free will and moral responsibility
quranic_references.judgment: Will be judged by God on Day of Judgment
quranic_references.iblis: Satan (Iblis) identified as a djinn who disobeyed God (Quran 18:50)

prophet_suleiman.name: Suleiman (Solomon)
prophet_suleiman.gift: God granted him power over djinn, wind, and ability to understand animals
prophet_suleiman.use: Commanded djinn to build temples, palaces, and perform great works

interaction_with_humans.possession: Djinn can possess humans (Islamic exorcism practices exist)
interaction_with_humans.communication: Can communicate with humans, may deceive or help
interaction_with_humans.protection: Quranic verses and prayers used for protection from harmful djinn

religious.sensitivity_note: Djinn are part of living Islamic religious belief. This is NOT folklore or mythology for millions of Muslims but theological reality. Respectful treatment is essential.
religious.respect_guidelines: Recognize Islamic religious context. Avoid mockery or trivialization. Distinguish between authentic Islamic theology and Western pop culture 'genies.' Do not conflate religious belief with superstition.

folklore.arabian_nights: Collection of Middle Eastern folk tales featuring djinn (though often embellished)
folklore.regional_traditions: Variations in djinn beliefs across different Islamic cultures
folklore.cautionary_tales: Stories warning of djinn trickery and danger

literature: "One Thousand and One Nights" (Arabian Nights) - Medieval folk tales
"The Golem and the Jinni" by Helene Wecker (2013)
games: Dungeons & Dragons - Genie-kin and djinn creatures
popular_culture.misrepresentation_note: Western 'genie' stereotype (three wishes, lamp/bottle imprisonment, comedic wish-granting) is largely inaccurate to Islamic theology and Arabian tradition. These tropes originated from folk tale adaptations and Victorian-era Orientalism.

researchers.name: Islamic scholars and theologians
researchers.contribution: Theological and exegetical work on djinn in Islamic texts

researchers.name: Anthropologists and folklorists
researchers.contribution: Study of djinn beliefs across Islamic cultures

research.ongoing_studies: Contemporary research examines djinn beliefs in modern Islamic societies, variations across cultures, relationship between religious doctrine and folk belief, and psychological/sociological aspects of djinn belief and exorcism practices.

sources.title: The Quran
sources.note: Primary Islamic scripture with extensive djinn references
